quiz.title: Algebra 2: Unit 13 Quiz 8
quiz.subtitle: 13.8: Solving Absolute Value Inequalities
quiz.subject: Mathematics
quiz.topic: Solving and graphing absolute value inequalities

questions.question: Which type of compound inequality is used to solve $|x| < 5$?
questions.explanation: A 'less than' absolute value inequality represents values whose distance from zero is small, creating a 'sandwich' or 'AND' interval.

questions.question: Which type of compound inequality is used to solve $|x| > 5$?
options: The set of all real numbers
questions.explanation: A 'greater than' absolute value inequality represents values far from zero in either the positive or negative direction, requiring an 'OR' statement.

questions.question: Solve $|2x - 3| \le 7$.
questions.explanation: $-7 \le 2x - 3 \le 7$. Adding 3 gives $-4 \le 2x \le 10$. Dividing by 2 gives $-2 \le x \le 5$.

questions.question: Solve $|x + 4| > 2$.
questions.explanation: Case 1: $x + 4 > 2 \implies x > -2$. Case 2: $x + 4 < -2 \implies x < -6$. This is an 'OR' statement.

questions.question: What is the solution to $|x - 5| < -2$?
questions.explanation: Absolute value represents distance, which is always 0 or positive. Distance can never be less than a negative number.

questions.question: What is the solution to $|x + 2| \ge 0$?
questions.explanation: Since absolute value always produces a non-negative result, the distance will always be greater than or equal to 0 for any real number $x$.

questions.question: Solve $3|x - 1| + 4 \le 10$.
questions.explanation: Isolate: $3|x - 1| \le 6 \implies |x - 1| \le 2$. Thus $-2 \le x - 1 \le 2$. Adding 1 gives $-1 \le x \le 3$.

questions.question: How is the solution to $|x + 3| \ge 4$ represented on a number line?
options: Two rays pointing in opposite directions starting from $-7$ and $1$.
A solid line segment connecting $-7$ and $1$.
A dashed line segment between $-4$ and $4$.
questions.explanation: $x + 3 \ge 4 \implies x \ge 1$. $x + 3 \le -4 \implies x \le -7$. This creates two separate rays on the number line.

questions.question: Solve $|4 - x| < 3$.
questions.explanation: $-3 < 4 - x < 3$. Subtract 4: $-7 < -x < -1$. Multiply by $-1$ (and flip signs): $7 > x > 1$ or $1 < x < 7$.

questions.question: In the inequality $|ax + b| > c$ (where $c > 0$), what happens to the solution set if $a$ is negative?
options: The inequality signs flip when you divide by $a$.
questions.explanation: Just like linear inequalities, dividing or multiplying by a negative number during the solving process requires reversing the inequality symbols.
